abstract.t: The Financial-grade API (FAPI) 2.0 Baseline profile is an API security profile based on the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework .

section.name: Introduction
section.t: Financial-grade API (FAPI) 2.0 is an API security profile based on the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework and related specifications suitable for protecting APIs in high-value scenarios. While the security profile was initially developed with a focus on financial applications, it is designed to be universally applicable for protecting APIs exposing high-value and sensitive (personal and other) data, for example, in e-health and e-government applications.

section.name: Baseline Profile
section.t: OIDF FAPI is an API security profile based on the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework . This Baseline Profile aims to reach the security goals laid out in the [Attacker Model].

section.name: Network Layer Protections
section.t: To protect against network attackers, clients, authorization servers, and resource servers shall only offer TLS protected endpoints and shall establish connections to other servers using TLS. TLS connections shall be set up to use TLS version 1.2 or later and follow .

Endpoints for the use by web browsers shall use methods to ensure that connections cannot be downgraded using TLS Stripping attacks. A preloaded HTTP Strict Transport Security policy can be used for this purpose. Some top-level domains, like .bank and .insurance, have set such a policy and therefore protect all second-level domains below them.

For a comprehensive protection against network attackers, all endpoints should additionally use DNSSEC to protect against DNS spoofing attacks that can lead to the issuance of rogue domain-validated TLS certificates. Note: Even if an endpoint uses only organization validated (OV) or extended validation (EV) TLS certificates, rogue domain-validated certificates can be used to impersonate the endpoints and conduct man-in-the-middle attacks. CAA records can help to mitigate this risk.

section.name: Profile
section.t: In the following, a profile of the following technologies is defined:

li.t: OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework
OAuth 2.0 Bearer Tokens
Proof Key for Code Exchange by OAuth Public Clients (PKCE)
OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS Client Authentication and Certificate-Bound Access Tokens (MTLS)
OAuth 2.0 Demonstrating Proof-of-Possession at the Application Layer (DPoP)
OAuth 2.0 Pushed Authorization Requests (PAR)
OAuth 2.0 Rich Authorization Requests (RAR)
OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server Metadata
OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server Issuer Identifier in Authorization Response
OpenID Connect Core 1.0 incorporating errata set 1

section.t: Authorization servers

shall support the authorization code grant described in
shall reject requests using the resource owner password credentials grant or the implicit grant described in
shall support client-authenticated pushed authorization requests according to
shall reject authorization requests sent without
shall reject pushed authorization requests without client authentication
shall support the authorization_details parameter according to to convey the authorization clients want to obtain if the scope parameter is not expressive enough for that purpose
shall support confidential clients as defined in
shall only issue sender-constrained access tokens using one of the following methods:
MTLS as described in
DPoP as described in
shall authenticate clients using one of the following methods:
MTLS as specified in section 2 of
private_key_jwt as specified in section 9 of
shall require PKCE with S256 as the code challenge method
shall require the redirect_uri parameter in pushed authorization requests
shall return an iss parameter in the authorization response according to

shall not transmit authorization responses over unencrypted network connections, and, to this end, shall not allow redirect URIs that use the "http" scheme except for native clients that use Loopback Interface Redirection as described in , Section 7.3,
shall reject an authorization code (section 1.3.1 of ) if it has been previously used

shall provide a means for resource servers to verify the validity, integrity, sender-constraining, scope (incl. authorization_details), expiration and revocation status of an access token, either by providing an introspection endpoint , by exposing signature verification keys, or by deployment-specific means.
should use the HTTP 303 status code when redirecting the user agent using status codes;

section.t: NOTE: In order to facilitate interoperability the authorization server should also accept its token endpoint URL or the URL of the endpoint at which the assertion was received in the aud claim received in client authentication assertions.

NOTE: If replay identification of the authorization code is not possible, it is desirable to set the validity period of the authorization code to one minute or a suitable short period of time. The validity period may act as a cache control indicator of when to clear the authorization code cache if one is used.
NOTE: To enable an interoperable solution to consent management it is anticipated that future versions of this specification will reference the FAPI WG's Grant Management API.

section.name: Returning Authenticated User's Identifier
section.t: If it is desired to provide the authenticated user's identifier to the client in the token response, the authorization server shall support OpenID Connect .

section.t: Clients

shall use pushed authorization requests according to

section.name: Requirements for Resource Servers
section.t: The FAPI 2.0 endpoints are OAuth 2.0 protected resource endpoints that return protected information for the resource owner associated with the submitted access token.
Resource servers with the FAPI endpoints

li.t: shall accept access tokens in the HTTP header as in Section 2.1 of OAuth 2.0 Bearer Token Usage
shall not accept access tokens in the query parameters stated in Section 2.3 of OAuth 2.0 Bearer Token Usage
shall verify the validity, integrity, expiration and revocation status of access tokens
shall verify that the scope (incl. authorization_details) of the access token authorizes the access to the resource it is representing
shall support and verify sender-constrained access tokens using one of the following methods:
MTLS as described in
DPoP as described in
shall identify the associated entity to the access token
shall only return the resource identified by the combination of the entity implicit in the access and the granted scope and otherwise return errors as in section 3.1 of
Authorization Servers, Clients, and Resource Servers shall adhere to when creating or processing JWTs. In particular,
the algorithm-specific recommendations in Section 3.2 shall be followed,
and the none algorithm shall not be used or accepted.
RSA keys shall have a minimum length of 2048 bits.
Elliptic curve keys shall have a minimum length of 160 bits.

Credentials not intended for handling by end-users (e.g., access tokens, refresh tokens, authorization codes, etc.) shall be created with at least 128 bits of entropy such that an attacker correctly guessing the value is computationally infeasible. Cf. Section 10.10 ofÂ .
